Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Controls Over Nitrogen Loss from Very Wet Tropical Forests
Award.AbstractNarration:
Humans have changed the global nitrogen cycle to an extraordinary degree. Such changes have brought clear benefits to society, but increasingly, the excess of nitrogen now present in many ecosystems is causing a litany of environmental and public health concerns. Thus, it has become critical to understand how ecosystems gain, store and lose nitrogen, and to do so in an increasingly varied range of ecosystems as changes in the nitrogen cycle become truly global in scope. This project seeks to understand the nitrogen balance of a tropical rainforest, in part because current and predicted future changes to the nitrogen cycle are most pronounced in the tropical portions of the world. The project explores why the wettest of tropical forests, as typified by a field site in southern Costa Rica, seem to exhibit a much different nitrogen cycle than do the drier portions of the tropical biome. A variety of techniques will be used ? ranging from watershed nitrogen balance, to isotopic measurements, to experimental fertilizer plots to explore how nitrogen is cycled within this ecosystem, and what forms of nitrogen dominate losses to the surrounding environment. Key aspects of the carbon and phosphorus cycles will be measured in tandem with a focus on nitrogen, because prior work in this site suggests that both elements may play important roles in determining the size and forms of nitrogen loss.

The wettest of tropical forests remain one of the more poorly studied ecosystems of the world, and yet they appear to be hotspots for carbon storage and for nutrient export to coastal oceans, as well as key regions for tropical forest conservation. This project will shed light on how such forests work on an ecosystem scale, thereby aiding the ability to predict how they may respond not only to a changing nitrogen cycle, but also to changes in climate and land use. The project will also provide support for numerous junior scientists, including an early stage assistant professor and several undergraduate and graduate students. Finally, the project will support a new collaboration between the P.I. and a professional journalist that is aimed at communicating the importance of tropical forests to a broader audience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project was a joint venture between the University of Colorado-Boulder and the University of Montana. The overarching goal of this project was to understand how climate, and rainfall in particular, affects nutrient cycling in very wet tropical forests. Our research efforts focused on understanding how high rainfall influences the nitrogen (N) cycle, as multiple lines of evidence suggest N availability and limitation may be fundamentally different in very wet forests than dryer tropical forests. Aspects of this work ranged from watershed-scale studies of nutrient leaching and export to rivers and streams, to explorations of rates and controls over biological N fixation, to landscape scale variation in N cycling that may arise across landscapes from low lying areas to more mountainous regions. Our work also included ecological synthesis to explore how interactions between rainfall and temperature across major tropical forest regions affect carbon gain and loss in the tropics, key players that regulate atmospheric carbon dioxide accumulation and the earth's climate system. 

Over the life of the project, our work culminated in several important advances and outcomes. First, our research showed that the major form of nitrogen loss from wet forests is as particulate organic N (PON), most of which results from surface soil erosion. This appears to be a major reason why these very wet tropical forests don't contain as much N fertility as other dryer tropical forests. Next, the work produced a novel way to estimate one of the most vexing but important sources of N in the tropical N cycle: symbiotic N fixation. That work suggests prior estimates of rainforest N fixation are substantially too high and provides a roadmap for refining such estimates further across the biome. Third, our work suggests that topographic and geologic variation across complex tropical forest landscapes leads to important differences in N availability and loss across the landscape, with more stable (e.g., flat) portions of the landscape able to accumulate N, while more dynamic (e.g., steep) portions remain N poor.  Fourth, synthetic work led by project postdoc Phil Taylor and PI Townsend shows that plant growth and decomposition does not decline in the wettest of lowland forests across the tropics, and may even show an increase up to values beyond 5m of rainfall per year. This result has important implications for understanding and forecasting responses of the tropical carbon cycle to changes in climate. Finally, initial analyses of the airborne remote sensing data show that our study region contains some of the highest plant biomass ever measured in lowland forests, and that landscape-scale variation in plant biomass is much more affected by community and population scale dynamics than by shifts in major environmental gradients.

Our project also had many outcomes beyond the scientific discoveries we made. The work supported nearly a dozen undergraduate and graduate students and postdocs at the early stages of their careers. We also performed a great deal of outreach work with Osa Conservation, a local NGO in Costa Rica that supported our fieldwork.
